message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest urge incontinence, which is caused by involuntary contractions of the bladder muscle. Antagonism of muscarinic M3 receptors can relax the bladder muscle and reduce these contractions, therefore it is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient. Agonism of muscarinic M2 receptors can reduce heart rate and blood pressure, which is not relevant to this patient’s condition. Antagonism of beta-3 adrenergic receptors and agonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors can increase bladder capacity, but they are not as effective as muscarinic antagonists for urge incontinence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are indicative of urge incontinence, which is caused by an overactive bladder. Antagonizing muscarinic M3 receptors can help relax the bladder and reduce the urge to urinate. The other options are not appropriate for treating urge incontinence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest an overactive bladder, which is caused by increased activity of muscarinic M3 receptors in the bladder. Antagonizing these receptors, such as with antimuscarinic drugs, can reduce urge incontinence and increase bladder capacity. The other options are not effective in treating overactive bladder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of urge incontinence, which is caused by overactivity of the detrusor muscle due to muscarinic M3 receptor stimulation. Antagonism of muscarinic M3 receptors is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest overactive bladder and the most appropriate pharmacotherapy is a drug that antagonizes muscarinic M3 receptors. Option B is also used for overactive bladder, but it agonizes beta-3 adrenergic receptors. Option C is used for asthma and bronchitis, and option D is used for bradycardia and atrioventricular block.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest urge incontinence, which is caused by detrusor muscle overactivity. Antagonism of muscarinic M3 receptors helps reduce detrusor muscle contractions and is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient. Agonism of beta-3 adrenergic receptors can also reduce detrusor muscle contractions but is less effective. Agonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors helps relax smooth muscle in the respiratory and cardiovascular systems, but not in the urinary system. Agonism of muscarinic M2 receptors can slow down the heart rate and may cause atrial fibrillation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with overactive bladder, which is treated with antimuscarinic drugs that antagonize the muscarinic M3 receptors. Option B, antagonism of beta-3 adrenergic receptors, is used to treat urge incontinence as well, but it’s less common. Option C, agonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors, is used to treat asthma and COPD, and option D agonism of muscarinic M2 receptors is used to treat bradycardia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest urge urinary incontinence, which is caused by detrusor overactivity. Antagonism of muscarinic M3 receptors can help relax the bladder and control symptoms. Option B is used to treat stress urinary incontinence, and options C and D are not used to treat urinary incontinence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of overactive bladder, where the detrusor muscle contracts involuntarily. Antagonism of muscarinic M3 receptors can relax the detrusor muscle and improve urinary symptoms. Antagonism of beta-3 adrenergic receptors can also improve symptoms, but it is not the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient. Agonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors and agonism of muscarinic M2 receptors are not effective treatments for overactive bladder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest urge incontinence, which is caused by overactive bladder muscles. Antagonism of muscarinic M3 receptors can help relax these muscles, therefore, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is a drug that has this mechanism of action.
